Award.AwardTitle: Spectral Tweets: A Community Paradigm for Spatio-temporal Cognitive Sensing and Access
Award.AbstractNarration: Advances in wireless communication, networking, and computation using miniaturized devices have come to a confluence that has greatly improved productivity even in traditionally "low-tech" sectors of the economy. The flip side is that demand for radio spectrum is on track to outpace advances in spectral efficiency. Innovative and pragmatic dynamic spectrum sensing and measurement-based spectrum access modalities are needed to bridge the gap, and support demand and the national economy in the not-so-distant future. It is now widely accepted that effective spectrum sensing must be a collaborative endeavor, involving many sensors taking relatively sparse measurements across space, time, and frequency. The vision and starting point of this project is that today's smart phones and tablets are ideal platforms for crowdsourcing spectrum sensing, and this is a viable way to create a spectrum sensing web that spans across much of our living and working space. But can all these devices be coordinated to produce local spectrum maps, reveal transmission opportunities, and enable intelligent dynamic access? An appealing idea is to employ Twitter as a service model to multicast short "spectral tweets." Devices will hook up to local communities based on GPS information, and set up "bots" to follow tweets from other devices in the neighborhood.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Effective space-time spectrum sensing and mapping are prerequisites for aggressive spectrum reuse, which is crucial for seamless connectivity between humans and the Internet of Things.  Today's smart phones, tablets, and smart sensors are ideal platforms for crowdsourcing spectrum sensing, and this is a viable way to create a spectrum sensing web that spans across much of our living and working space. But how can all these devices be coordinated to produce local spectrum maps, reveal transmission opportunities, and enable intelligent dynamic access? Finding answers to these questions was the overarching goal of this project.

Intellectual merit: The theoretical results of this project have paved the way for crowdsourcing spectrum sensing and mapping tasks to ad-hoc networks of mobile wireless devices. The theoretical and algorithmic problems considered are challenging, because they require a combination of knowledge and skills in wireless communications, signal processing, optimization, and machine learning. Working synergistically, the co-PIs and their students have contributed significant advances in a number of areas, including model-based distributed spectrum sensing (e.g., using dictionary learning); maximum likelihood passive and active spectrum sensing from heavily compressed distributed power measurements; unsupervised power spectra separation and emitter localization from distributed power measurements; wireless network anomaly and `cascade’ detection; adaptive low-complexity high-performance multicast beamforming; very low rate (`frugal’) channel estimation and tracking; power spectrum mapping using basis expansion, kernel, and dictionary learning models; state-of-art interference alignment algorithms; and quantized dictionary learning algorithms and their performance analysis.   

Broader impacts:  A US patent on non-parametric power spectral density mapping was granted as a result of this project, and another patent on downlink channel tracking using very-low-rate feedback is currently under second-round review by the USPTO. Two Ph.D. students have graduated and now work for the US wireless industry, and two more are nearing graduation, all with significant support from this grant. Several female and minority students have been involved in the research. Undergraduate students have been involved in app development and practical implementation of a prototype crowdsourced spectrum sensing system using short Twitter “tweets” to webcast local spectrum reports, motivating them to pursue careers in the wireless industry or to continue wireless research in graduate school. Several of the participants have won prestigious University-level (University of Minnesota Doctoral Dissertation Fellowship) as well as international conference best paper awards.  Other graduate students at the M.Sc. level have been involved in the research and laboratory work, and now continue towards their Ph.D. Many high-quality journal papers have been published, and the co-PIs have given related plenaries, keynotes, tutorials and colloquia around the world.
